content: 82 | Simpson Strong‑Tie® Timber Construction Connectors C‑C‑AU16 © 2016 Simpson Strong‑Tie Company Inc. serutcurtS roodtuO Rigid Tie Connectors Outdoor Structures RT Rigid Tie Connectors The Rigid Tie™ RTC series secures two timber members to a vertical post forming a 90° corner. The RTC42 and RTC44 are heavy‑duty structural connectors. • RTA—connects two 45mm timber members at a 90° angle. • RTF—connects two members in a “pass‑through” application. Material: RTA – 1.6mm thick; all others 1.3mm thick. Finish: Galvanised; Some products available in ZMAX® coating. See Corrosion Information. Installation • Use all specified fasteners. See General Notes. • Install vertical members first, then attach horizontal members for easier alignment. • Seat timber member in bracket with a C‑clamp before securing to aid positioning and prevent skewing. To learn more about the new WBSK Workbench and Shelving • Always follow manufacturer’s instructions when using Unit Hardware Kit that includes power tools and building equipment. RTC2Zs, fasteners and plans to build a workbench or shelving unit, visit www.diydoneright.com. RTC2Z RTA2Z RTT2Z RTF2Z

Simpson Strong‑Tie® Timber Construction Connectors | 85 serutcurtS roodtuO Round Post Connectors Square Post Connectors Outdoor Structures RFC/PPJ Round and Square Post Connectors The RFC fence connectors help make building a strong fence with round posts and rails easier. • The rounded flanges are designed to cradle the timber to provide support and a secure connection. • RFC is available for 80mm and 120mm posts, and both sizes install with 10mm bolts or screws (not included). The PPJ post bases are ideal for small, non‑load‑bearing projects as well as temporary structures. They are not recommended for structural applications or non‑top‑supported installations such as fences. Material: RFC—2.0mm thick; PJRB100—2.0mm thick; PPJBT—2.5mm thick. Finish: Galvanised. See Corrosion Information. Installation • Use all specified fasteners. See General Notes. • RFC—10mm diameter Hot‑dipped galvanised bolts or screws. • PPJ—Post: 10mm diameter Hot‑dipped galvanised bolts or screws. Base: Mechanical anchor (WA10083MG) or AT‑HP™ anchoring adhesive and threaded rod (RFB10X130HDG). Caution This range is not suitable for structural applications. The PGT is suitable for standard applications as well as corners and splices. • The PGT1.5Z‑R is for 38mm pipe (48mm outside diameter). • The PGT2Z‑R for 50mm pipe (60mm outside diameter). • The PGTIC2Z‑R is an interior corner pipe grip tie. Material: 2.7mm thick. Finish: PGT2‑R—galvanised; PGTIC2Z, PGT1.5Z, PGT2Z‑R—ZMAX® coating. See Corrosion Information. Installation • Use all specified fasteners. See General Notes. • PGTIC2Z‑R to Post ‑ install two set screws (supplied) with 3/8" hex socket in predrilled holes. • PGTIC2Z‑R to Rails ‑ use Simpson Strong‑Tie® Strong‑Drive® 6.4 x 38mm SDS Heavy‑Duty Connector screws (not supplied). • Install on vertical pipes, offsetting corners to allow for the correct rail alignment. • Use 3 to 4 PGTs per pipe; line up to stringline. • Fasten PGT with 6mm hex head bolt (supplied). • PGT attaches to rails with four 6.4 x 38mm SDS Heavy‑Duty Connector screws (not supplied). See SDS screw information. PGT2Z‑R • 6mm cup head bolts may be used. Follow the code requirements for pre‑drilling.

It is great for use in tight spaces where using a hammer is inconvenient. The #8 x 32mm SD Connector wafer‑head screw is ideal for miscellaneous fastening applications. The needle point ensures fast starts and deep #2 Phillips drive reduces cam‑out and stripping. Mechanically galvanized coating meets ASTM B695 Class 55, is recommended 1/4" washer head stamped for use with certain preservative‑treated with No‑Equal symbol and woods and recognized as an alternate length for easy inspection to hot‑dip galvanized in ESR‑3046 Shank size optimised and tested for use with Simpson Strong‑Tie connectors Wafer‑Head Screw SD8x1.25 is a general timber‑to‑timber fastener, used in non‑structural applications Sharp point for faster starts Material: Heat‑treated carbon steel Finish: SD8x1.25—Electro Galvanised; SD—Mechanically galvanised (ASTM B695 Class 55) Warning: Industry studies show that hardened fasteners can experience performance problems in wet or corrosive environments.

content: 94 | Simpson Strong‑Tie® Timber Construction Connectors C‑C‑AU16 © 2016 Simpson Strong‑Tie Company Inc. smetsyS gninetsaF dna srohcnA etercnoC Fastening Systems Strong-Drive® SDWS TIMBER Screw The Strong‑Drive® SDWS Timber screw is designed to provide an easy‑to‑install, high‑strength alternative to through‑bolting and traditional coach screws. The new SDWS Timber screw is specifically designed for structural timber‑to‑timber applications and is also ideal for a wide variety of projects where a high‑strength attachment is needed – for the contractor and do‑it‑yourselfer alike. Under‑head nibs offer greater Deep, 6‑lobe recess reduces installer control when seating the head cam‑out, making driving easier Large washer head provides maximum bearing area Double‑barrier coating provides corrosion resistance equivalent to hot‑dip galvanisation, making it suitable for certain exterior and preservative‑treated timber applications Bold thread design provides superior holding power Low‑profile head design provides a clean look and less interference after installation Patented 4CUT™ tip ensures fast starts, reduces installation torque and eliminates the need for pre‑drilling in most applications Maximum bearing area The combination of a large washer head and bold thread design firmly secures timbers together to close gaps in multi‑timber connection assemblies Material: Heat‑treated carbon steel Finish: Double‑barrier coating.

chunk_id: Simpson Strong-Tie Timber Construction Connectors Catalog_p94_c1
source: Simpson Strong-Tie Timber Construction Connectors Catalog
content: on of a large washer head and bold thread design firmly secures timbers together to close gaps in multi‑timber connection assemblies Material: Heat‑treated carbon steel Finish: Double‑barrier coating. Screws with double barrier coatings are not used in exterior environments where there is airborne salinity or salinity splash. Installation • See General Notes. • Strong‑Drive SDWS Timber screws install best with a low‑speed 13mm drill and a T‑40 6‑lobe bit. The matched bit included with the screws is recommended for best results. • Pre‑drilling is typically not required. Where pre‑drilling is necessary, use a 5/32" or 4.00mm drill bit. • Screw heads that are countersunk flush to the timber surface are acceptable if the screw has not spun out.

Simpson Strong‑Tie® Timber Construction Connectors | 97 smetsyS gninetsaF dna srohcnA etercnoC Fastening Systems Strong-Drive® WSNTL SUBFLOOR Screw Collated Screws Exceed Values of Nails WSNTL wood screws are ideal for fastening subfloor, bracing, sill plate and stair applications using the Simpson Strong‑Tie® Quik Drive® auto‑feed screw driving system. With withdrawal and pull‑through values that exceed those of 3.75mm nails, the holding power of WSNTL screws reduces the gaps between the joist and subfloor that cause floor squeaks. Our auto‑feed screw driving system increases productivity, reducing costs. Using screws that can be backed out easily allows future access to floor cavities. Features • Eliminates subfloor nail squeaking and costly call backs • Variety of lengths to cover subfloor, wall plates, and stair treads • WSNTL screw design draws subfloor and joist tightly together, giving visual confirmation of proper screw placement See the Difference on the Jobsite The WSNTL wood screw gives visual confirmation of a secure joist connection by countersinking, while “shot‑in” pneumatic fasteners look the same whether or not they hit the joist. Missed fasteners could result in floor flexing that can cause squeaking in other parts of the structure and reduced diaphragm load capacity. content: Frequently Asked Questions Building and Product Information What is a connector? Structural connectors are made out of steel, and are engineered to connect and strengthen the frame of a building. Reinforcing the frame of a building with structural connectors helps the building resist damage caused by earthquakes, high winds and cyclones. Framing materials secured with connectors are much stronger than those secured only with nails (called toenailing). Connectors come in all shapes and sizes, and have a variety of names, such as joist hangers, holdowns and hurricane ties. Homeowners don’t typically see connectors in their homes because they are covered up behind the walls. Crawl Space Perimeter Wall Rim Joist Floor System Top Plates A35 What is a shearwall? Fr A a n m gl i e ng Shearwalls are reinforced walls within a building that Ventilation Holes have been engineered to help resist the shear (racking) forces caused by high winds or the lateral forces caused Cripple Wall Bracing by earthquakes. Shearwalls are typically constructed by attaching timber bracing and holdown connectors Titen HD® anchor with washer to a section of the timber framing along a wall. To learn more, visit Build with a Continuous Load Path www.safestronghome.com/protect/02.asp When framing a house, why is it better to use connectors than the traditional practice of toenailing? Framing materials held together with structural connectors can withstand much stronger forces than those held together with nails. Connectors have a higher load capacity than nails (see example at right). In a high wind storm, for example, nails are much more likely to pull apart or pop out than a metal connector. A connection made with a metal connector can be pulled apart, but it takes much greater force to separate it than a simple toenailed connection. A building built with connectors is better Toenail connection load capacity: Connector load capacity: 1.30kN 4.7kN able to resist forces from high winds and earthquakes. Simpson Strong‑Tie recommends inspecting your deck at least Well‑built decks made out of timber should last 10–15 years once a year. A good time to do this is the beginning of spring with proper inspection and maintenance. before you and your family start using your deck regularly. Can I repair my deck myself? A skilled homeowner can tackle most deck repair projects. However, if you’re not handy in construction, Simpson Strong‑Tie highly recommends working with a qualified, professional home surveyor or structural engineer to perform a structural evaluation and then a licensed contractor to do the work for you. When hiring a design professional, you want to make sure they are licensed and have a good reputation. It’s also a good idea to understand the work that is to be done and get involved in the process, so that you can make sure the project is done right. References are AS 1604, ISO 9223, AS 1684.2 (appendix B), AS 1684.4, AS 4534 (appendix F), and NZ3604. These are general guidelines that may not consider all application criteria. Refer to product specific information for additional guidance. 2. Treatments typical of Hazard Classes H1 and H2 are based on inorganic boron or are preservatives in light organic solvents (LOSP). 3. Treatments typical of Hazard Class H3 is ACQ-D (retention 6.4 kg/m3), Copper Azole-B (retention 3.3 kg/m3), Copper Azole-C (retention 2.4 kg/m3) 4.

chunk_id: Simpson Strong-Tie NZS 3604 Timber Connectors_p4_c1
source: Simpson Strong-Tie NZS 3604 Timber Connectors
content: e preservatives in light organic solvents (LOSP). 3. Treatments typical of Hazard Class H3 is ACQ-D (retention 6.4 kg/m3), Copper Azole-B (retention 3.3 kg/m3), Copper Azole-C (retention 2.4 kg/m3) 4. Treatments for sawn products typical of Hazard Classes H4, H5, and H6 are CCA, ACZA, ACQ (retention > 6.4 kg/m3), and creosote. 5. Fire-retardant treated timber may have specific corrosion resistance requirements. See chemical manufacturer guidelines. 6. Type 316/305/304 stainless steels are recommended where preservative treated timber is used in ground contact. 7. Testing by Simpson Strong-Tie following ICC-ES AC257 has shown that mechanical galvanisation, Quik Guard coating, and Double Barrier coating will provide corrosion resistance equivalent to hot-dip galvanisation in contact with chemically treated timber in dry service and wet service exposures (Hazard Classes H1-H3) and will perform adequately subject to regular maintenance and periodic inspection. 8. Mechanical galvanisations C3 and N2000 should not be used in conditions that would be more corrosive than Hazard Class H3 (external, above ground rapid water run off). 9. If uncertain about Hazard Class, treatment chemical, or environment, use Type 316/305/304 stainless steels, silicon bronze, or copper. 10. Type 316 stainless steel, silicon bronze, and copper fasteners are the best recommendation for ocean front and chloride-containing environments.

The DTT2Z tension tie is designed for lighter-duty holdown applications on single or double studs. It installs easily with the Strong-Drive® SDS Heavy-Duty Connector screws (included). The HTT4 tension tie installs with nails and features a nailing pattern that provides better results with less deflection. 40 mm 40 mm The HDU8 Holdown is pre-deflected during the manufacturing process, virtually eliminating deflection under load due to material stretch. They install with Simpson Strong-Tie® DTT2Z Strong-Drive® SDS Heavy-Duty Connector screws which install easily, reduce (DTT2SS similar) fastener slip and provide a greater net section when compared to bolts. For more information on holdown options, contact Simpson Strong-Tie. Material: 1.6 mm thick Finish: DTT2Z in ZMAX®, DTT2SS in 316L SS, HTT4 and HDU8 in Z275 coating. See Corrosion Information. source: Simpson Strong-Tie NZS 3604 Timber Connectors
content: s are value engineering at its finest. All hangers in the LUS 25.4 mm series have Double-Shear Nailing. This innovation distributes the load through two points on each joist nail for greater strength. It also allows the use of fewer nails, faster installation and the use of standard nails for all connections. To help with installation speed every galvanised LUS Joist Hanger incorporates the Simpson Strong-Tie Speed Prong feature which is designed to temporarily position and secure the connector for easier and faster installation. Material: 1.2 mm thick. Finish: ZMAX® coating or 316L SS. See Corrosion Information. content: Simpson Strong-Tie® Timber Connectors — NZS 3604 Characteristic Capacities Deck Tension Ties/Ballustrade Restraint The DTT1Z and DTT2Z tension ties are safe, cost-effective connectors designed to help build stronger, safer decks that meet or exceed code requirements. The DTT1 is an easy-to-install method to provide a lateral-load connection between the deck and the adjacent structure. The DTT2 can be used for the lateral-load connection as well, but is ideal for the installation of guardrail posts that are able to resist the lateral forces that occur at the top of railing assemblies. chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p6_c0
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: Foreword NZSIP Ltd manufacture, supply and install Structural Insulated Panels (SIPs) to form walls and roof structures for residential buildings in New Zealand. Typical NZSIP Smart Panels comprise of StrandBoard (SB) nominally 12mm thick foamed and bonded to a core of Polyurethane Insulation (PUR). Panels are nominally 1205mm wide with varying lengths and heights depending on the design location of the panel. Flexible roof and wall underlays must comply with NZBC Acceptable Solution E2/AS1 Table 23 or a breather-type membrane covered by a valid BRANZ Appraisal for use as a roof and wall underlays. Sealing tapes must be compatible with roof and wall underlays and SB substrate. Individual wall panels have a wall underlay vapour control layer adhered to the external face. The external wall envelope is clad over a drained cavity, the internal face is lined over a cavity to provide for electrical services. Roof Purlin Fixing. Roof purlins are 70mm x 45mm SG8 H1.2 and fixed using 8g x 75mm square drive stainless steel screws. The fixing spacing and purlin spacing can be selected for different wind zones using the relevant tables included in the technical literature in this document.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p6_c1
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: 5mm square drive stainless steel screws. The fixing spacing and purlin spacing can be selected for different wind zones using the relevant tables included in the technical literature in this document. Joints between adjacent panels are taped and foamed with Gorilla Pro Expanding foam A simple to use cam lock system quickly pulls the Smart Panels together during the construction process, making for an easy, fast install and a strong bond between each panel, allowing you to create an airtight SIPs building envelope. The continuous PUR insulation ensures that thermal bridging is kept to a minimum. Once the windows are installed – the Smart walls, roof and or floors provide a structure that is weather resistant and vapour permeable. Service channels and structural timber can be installed in the panels when and where required as each Smart Panel is custom manufactured for the home. We are proud to be New Zealand’s manufacturer of structural insulated panels.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p7_c0
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: BACKGROUND INFORMATION Innovation in the building industry over the last fifty years has focussed on improving the thermal performance of buildings, reducing building waste, using more lightweight materials and enabling faster methods of construction. First developed in the 1930’s, Structural Insulated Panels (or SIPs) delivers all of these benefits and offers a real alternative to traditional timber framing. SIPs are a high-performance building system for low rise construction. They are manufactured under factory controlled conditions and can be fabricated to suit most building designs. The end result is a building system that is extremely strong, energy efficient and cost-effective Highly insulated and airtight, the Smart SIP Building System is an affordable, next- generation solution to building a comfortable, healthy, energy-efficient home.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p8_c0
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: SCOPE,INTERPRETATION AND DEFINITIONS The scope of use – Buildings up to 10 m height NZSIP Smart Panel up to NZS 3604 Extra High Wind Zone (Note site specific factors may require adjustments) The NZSIP Smart Panel Building System is suitable for single or multi-unit (detached) Risk Group SH housing which meets the scope of Clause 1.1.2 of NZS3604 with the following limitations: ● detached housing 1m or more from the relevant boundary, and, ● the ground floor construction platform must compromise of a concrete slab on ground constructed in accordance with NZS 3604, or a suspended timber framed floor supported on a concrete wall or piled foundation constructed in accordance with NZS 3604; and, ● the first (upper) floor is a suspended timber floor constructed in accordance with NZS 3604; and, ● the first-floor live load does not exceed 1.5 kPa; and, ● roof construction comprising trusses and roof framing which meet the provisions of NZS 3604; and/or, ● where the roof is constructed solely using NZSIP Smart Panel’s supported on beams these are specific engineering design, SED, and, ● situated in NZS 3604 Wind Zones, up to and including ‘Extra High’ or as evaluated by testing/assessment; and ● in all NZS 3604 Earthquake Zones; and ● with a NZS 3604 classified Light Roof of profiled metal roof cladding; and ● roof and wall claddings must comply with NZBC E2/AS1 or a current BRANZ Appraised system; and, ● with a roof pitch between 3° and 30°.

content: 3604 classified Light Roof of profiled metal roof cladding; and ● roof and wall claddings must comply with NZBC E2/AS1 or a current BRANZ Appraised system; and, ● with a roof pitch between 3° and 30°. ● refer to Figure 1.1 Flowchart for limitations and scope of NZS 3604. ● the use of NZSIP Smart Panels in locations where they may be affected by high levels of moisture and/or heat, such as indoor pools, saunas and steam rooms, is not permitted. The scope of application of all designs and construction shall be within the limits set out in the November 2021 V2 technical manual and shall be within the requirements and the tables set out in this manual. Always check that you have the latest version of this manual. Updates or version number is available at www.nzsip.co.nz or email enquiries@nzsip.co.nz. Any changes in design or construction from the information contained herein must be confirmed in writing to an NZSIP representative or relevant engineer and signed off by an NZSIP representative and will be outside the scope of this technical manual. Specifier If you are a specifier or other responsible party for a project, ensure that the information in this document is appropriate for the application you are planning and that you undertake specific design and detailing for areas which fall outside the scope of these specifications. Please note, NZSIP Smart Panels must be considered as one part of a wider strategy of improving energy efficiency in construction. Windows, foundation systems and ventilation strategy all play an important role in achieving energy efficiency. For this reason, we recommend the engagement of suitably qualified consultants to provide advice on how to best employ our product in your project. Please refer to our website for details. Installer If you are an installer ensure that you follow the NZSIP installation manual, design principles, moisture management, associated details and material selection provided by the designer. All the details in this document must be read in conjunction with the specifier’s specification. As the installer, you must be a licensed building practitioner or have one supervising. All work shall be carried out to current best trade practise by experienced and competent tradesmen, familiar with the materials and installation techniques and as shown on the drawings. 1.2 Tolerances Floor platforms must be constructed such that they are the correct dimensions, flat, straight, parallel, square and set to the exact level. A guide to the recommended tolerances based on NZS 3604 Table 2.1 is given below: 1.3 Co-Operation Cooperate with other trades to ensure that all preliminary and preparatory works are completed to specification and as shown on the drawings prior to installation. Coordinate with other trades as required.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p11_c0
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: 1.4 Weather Exposure The building envelope must be fully enclosed and weatherproof, with any timber framing exposed at or below the required moisture content, before membrane installation commences. Once the wall panels have been erected the roof panels should be put on as soon as possible, preferably with the purlins and roof underlay and roofing, alternatively tarpaulins to mitigate the SB getting wet. If there is a delay in putting the wall underlay up then an assessment of the SB should be made before applying it. Although there is a notional 90 day exposure for the SB this should be kept to the absolute minimum if possible and the SB kept dry before installing the underlay. 1.5 Maintenance NZSIP Smartpanels must be kept dry after close-in. The external envelope must be maintained to prevent ingress of water and internal water sources such as leaks must be repaired promptly. If damage due to prolonged wetting does occur, contact NZSIP Limited for guidance with repair or replacement methods. A document detailing the maintenance requirements should be placed in a suitable location in every SIP Smart panel house. To the homeowner/occupier. This house is constructed using the NZSIP Smart panel Building System. Like all houses it requires regular maintenance. Regular maintenance is required to meet the performance requirements of the New Zealand Building Code and will enhance the serviceable life of the building materials used.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p11_c1
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: equires regular maintenance. Regular maintenance is required to meet the performance requirements of the New Zealand Building Code and will enhance the serviceable life of the building materials used. Attention to the following is required: • Ensure adequate ventilation to wet areas is maintained. • Ensure internal linings, floor covering and finishing, including joints, openings and the perimeters are maintained to provide protection from internal moisture. Ensure that Smartpanel wall and ceiling surfaces are not exposed to sustained high humidity, liquid water or high temperatures. • Regularly inspect (at least yearly) the external cladding and roofing systems and repair any damage or deterioration to prevent water ingress. • Maintain minimum floor clearances: concrete floors – 150mm to permanent paving – 225mm to unprotected ground. Refer to the New Zealand Building Code Acceptable Solution E2/AS1. Contact NZSIP Limited, the suppliers of Smart Panel, for further detail.

content: 1.6 Durability Durability is covered in the New Zealand Building code (NZBC) in section B2 – Durability and Section E2 – External moisture. NZSIP Smart Panels are designed to meet these NZBC conditions, with Smart Panel Panel material consistency and specifications being checked in the factory according to the Manufacturing Quality Manual which is maintained by the Factory management team. Providing that panels are then constructed according to the supplied panel plan and under conditions and requirements defined in NZSIP Ltd Installation Manual, Smart Panels will function for a specified intended life of not less than 50 years. An acceptable solution to the building code is referenced in B2/AS1 where the New Zealand standards NZS3604 and NZS3602 specify the level of treatment and the application respectively. Alternative solutions may be accepted by Territorial Authorities if the solution meets the durability requirements of the Building Code. *For further information please refer to our durability statement a copy of which can be emailed to you upon request. 2.

content: 2.3 Timber Grade and Quality Unless otherwise noted or specified on the drawings or specification, all framing timber shall be minimum structural grade SG8 Radiata pine in accordance with NZS 3622. Panels are manufactured with embedded framing at locations as required by the building specific engineering design (SED). The timber framing is LVL, treated to meet the requirements of H1.2 and with a stress grade dependent on location and SED. Embedded framing is used as supports for load bearing elements at openings such as windows and doors. Header panels and solid lintel panels are used at openings. Bottom plates are sized to suit the wall panel size and are solid timber SG8 or LVL8, treated H1.2. For 115mm Smart walls bottom plate is 90 x 45mm. For 165mm Smart walls bottom plate is 140mm x 45mm. Bottom plate may include a H3.1 treated plywood strip to raise the wall SB edges off the floor. For details refer to the Technical Literature. Framing timber shall be seasoned or kiln dried, and be straight and true and free from wind, warp and distortion, and in lengths suitable for the members required, and shall

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p20_c0
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: have a moisture content of between 12% and 18% before installation. Do not use damaged, faulty or defective materials. 2.4 Timber Treatment All non-durable timber framing shall be appropriately treated against moisture and/or insect decay by treatment plants with recognised quality assurance systems that are administered by the Timber Preservation Council (NZTPC). Treatment of timber and wood-based building products shall be to the requirements of NZS 3602 as an absolute minimum, and all treated timber shall be identified and marked as required. Carefully manage treated framing during installation to avoid accidental use of timber with a lower performance or durability treatment than that required or specified. 2.5 Polyurethane insulation Injection formed during panel fabrication. The PUR core is low VOC, zero Ozone depletion potential and low Global Warming Potential (GWP). Structural insulated panels are one of the most environmentally responsible building systems available. A SIP building envelope provides: ● higher levels of insulation ● greater reduction of thermal bridging ● is extremely airtight ● allows for better control over indoor air quality ● reduces construction waste, and helps save natural resources. Life cycle analysis has shown that SIP homes have a tremendous positive environmental impact by reducing energy use and greenhouse gas emissions throughout the home’s life cycle.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p20_c1
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: ve natural resources. Life cycle analysis has shown that SIP homes have a tremendous positive environmental impact by reducing energy use and greenhouse gas emissions throughout the home’s life cycle. Rigid Closed Cell PolyUrethane Foam (PUR) foam insulation is thermoset into each of our custom built Smart Panels. When cured it becomes chemically inert & will not outgas any harmful chemicals; there is also no formaldehyde in PUR foam. The HFC blowing agent that helps to generate the closed cell bubbles in the foam has Low Global Warming Potential (GWP) and Zero Ozone Depletion Potential (ODP) - The Thermal Conductivity of the PUR foam (allowing for time dependent effects) is - 0.023 W/mK-1. Polyurethane foam insulation, due to its non sagging, water- phobic and adhesive qualities it will perform at optimal levels for the foreseeable life of the building

content: 2.6 Formaldehyde Strandboard® complies with the E0 category of AS/NZS 1859.1:2017 when tested to AS/NZS 4266.16. During construction and after close-in formaldehyde emission levels can be best controlled by room ventilation and sealing or covering the surface facing the habitable space. 2.7 Strand Board (SB) Strandboard® is a versatile reconstituted wood panel manufactured entirely from renewable plantation pine timber. It is designed specifically for a range of building and furniture & joinery applications. Strandboard® is identified by its characteristic wood strand surface. The resin used has been developed to resist the effects of moisture in areas of high humidity and reduce the emission of formaldehyde. Timber shall be straight and true and free from wind, warp and distortion, and shall have a moisture content of between 12% and 18% before installation. Do not use damaged, faulty or defective materials. 2.8 Wall Underlay Flexible roof and wall underlays must comply with NZBC acceptable solution E2/AS1 Table 23 or breather-type membranes covered by a valid BRANZ Appraisal for use as roof or wall underlays. The NZSIP Smart Panel Building System will contribute to the cladding system compliance with NZBC Clause E2.3.2. Sealing tapes must be compatible with roof and wall underlays and SB substrate. 2.9 Joints & Penetrations The Smart Panel system delivers superior airtightness and durability over traditional timber frame construction.

content: 3. Design Design Procedure When designing a NZSIP Smart Panel structure, the following process is recommended: • Draw the floor layout plan as desired within the scope of the particular District Scheme. • Choose the roof and wall cladding systems to be used • Choose the level of insulation required for the site location. • Design the foundations and the building platform in accordance with NZS 3604, NZS 4229. • Determine the bracing requirements from NZS 3604:2011 and calculate the bracing values of the panels (refer to the relevant Section (Bracing) of this manual). • Design the roof construction and/or trusses to comply with the truss designer’s requirements and NZS 3604:2011. General Design Rules Building Geometry Gable, Monopitch and lean-to roof forms are the most straightforward geometry for designing with SIPs. These forms can be combined to provide more design options whilst maintaining simplicity.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p24_c0
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: More complex roof forms such as hips, valleys, dormers and flat roofs will require careful consideration and detailing and should be discussed first with NZSIP. If roof overhangs are required, these should be formed using purlins and/or outriggers as per NZS3604 10.2.1.15 or SED Panel Geometry While panels are 100% customisable, the best panel production efficiency is achieved by considering stock panel sizes; namely the 1200 x 3600mm module. Roof spans longer than 3600mm should be reduced by employing additional lines of support in the form of beams or load bearing walls.Roof panels can be joined in the factory to create a longer span however this falls under SED At the other end of the scale, minimum panel sizes should be considered. When setting out openings, ensure there is sufficient space to form lintels above windows.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p25_c0
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: Structural considerations around lintels sizes/grades will normally determine minimum dimensions in these areas. Also ensure there is sufficient space to form panels between windows and between windows and corners/other obstructions. Normally we recommend at least 300mm. If less space is required, please note that the supplied panels may be solid timber, or we may recommend a supporting timber post is installed onsite. Engineering To resolve all structural requirements for a project, engage an engineer as soon as possible in the design process. When it is practical and cost effective, structural components (such as timber beam pockets and posts) can be included in the panel manufacture. Steelwork We recommend that any steel structure (beams, columns or portals) be located to the interior of the building, as opposed to inline, or in the same plane as the panels. This eliminates any potential thermal bridging and condensation issues and ensures construction sequence flows smoothly. If steelwork within the panels is being considered, discuss with NZSIP prior to inclusion in documentation. Detailing Please refer to the standard details during the design process and when assembling documentation for construction. The standard details represent best practice and ensure that your project will achieve all the benefits of speed of assembly and thermal performance.

Site Requirements 4.1 Preparation 4.1.1 Storage & Handling Check SIPs upon delivery and reject sub-standard or damaged material. Store panels dry under cover, fillet stacked and well clear of the ground, and protect from damage, moisture, and contamination. Ensure all appropriate personal protection equipment is worn at all times when handling. 4.1.2 Concrete Separation Confirm whether there is or could possibly be a requirement to separate SIPs with an approved continuous damp proof course when in direct contact with concrete or masonry. Ensure that the DPC material is compatible with the timber treatment.

content: 4.1.4 Preparation Cooperate with other trades to ensure that all preliminary and preparatory works are completed to specification and as shown on the drawings. Coordinate with other trades to install products as required. All installation work shall be carried out by experienced and competent installers, familiar with the specified products and installation techniques, in accordance with the manufacturer’s installation requirements and as shown on the drawings. Store products undercover on a flat dry surface off the floor. Keep dry and out of direct sunlight and protect from damage at all times. Handle products in accordance with the manufacturers requirements. The building envelope must be fully enclosed and weatherproof, with timber framing at or below the required moisture content, before membrane installation commences. Check that the framing construction is complete with all necessary insulation, plumbing, wiring and ducting services installed and complete, ready for pro clima installation. Check framing for fixings, splinters and other unnecessary protrusions likely to cause punctures. 5. source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: 5.5 Joints & Penetrations The Smart Panel system delivers superior airtightness and durability over traditional timber frame construction. A key component of this system is the sealing of all internal panel joints and penetrations with compatible air sealing products. Air sealing tapes, adhesives and pipe and cable sealing grommets are to be installed to the inside face of structural insulated wall and roof panels at all joint and penetration locations. All aspects of this work shall be in accordance with the standard details and manufacturers instructions. Walls panels ● Panel joints - all junctions between wall panels, headers, footers & gables, ● corner junctions - all internal and external corners ● floor junctions - ensure coverage of packing under bottom plate and seal to concrete for concrete slab floors ● window and door openings ● service penetrations - ensure all penetrations are completed at the pre lining stage Roof panels ● Panel joints - all junction between roof panels ● Ridge & beam junctions - ensure full coverage of beams, including joint between built up members and pocket to wall panels. ● Gable and eave junctions - ensure coverage of timber wedge at eave. ● Roof light openings ● service penetrations - ensure all penetrations are completed at the pre lining stage 5.6 Blower door testing As a check on the quality of construction, we recommend blower door testing at the pre-lining stage.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p29_c1
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: enetrations - ensure all penetrations are completed at the pre lining stage 5.6 Blower door testing As a check on the quality of construction, we recommend blower door testing at the pre-lining stage. Blower door testing is performed using a special fan and frame that fits within an external door frame, The building is then pressurized and unpressurized with the airflow results logged against the building’s volume. Results are typically presented as the number of air changes (the total internal volume) per hour @ 50 pa. We recommend a Target air infiltration (air leakage) rate of less than 1.5 ach-1 @50Pa. Refer also to sections on internal moisture and thermal performance.

Construction sites can contain multiple hazards and it is essential that installers follow all legal requirements when working on site. Please refer to the OSH regulations for all relevant legislation. The Smart Panel instal manual outlines specific handling and installation of panels and recommends tools and accessories. 6. Foundation & Subfloor Framing 7.1 Foundation and Subfloor Construction The foundation and subfloor construction as given in: • NZS 3604: 2011 (timber & concrete) • NZS 4229 (concrete masonry and timber floors) • By specific design in accordance with NZBC B1/VM1

DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
Based on the provided context and description of the construction detail:

1. **Components Shown**:
   - **Bracing**: Structural bracing element illustrated, possibly made of steel or engineered wood.
   - **Hold Down Bolt**: A bolt with an accompanying washer (50x50x3mm).
   - **Bottom Plate**: A framing component where the hold down is anchored.
   - **Framing System**: Surrounding framing members that interact with the bracing and bottom plate.

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings**:
   - The hold down bolt must be fitted within **50mm** of the strap.
   - The hold down bolt must be **100mm** from the end of the bracing.
   - Bracing strap connection is indicated with a length of **150mm** and a width of **25mm** (0.9mm thickness).

3. **Assembly Order or Installation Sequence**:
   - Install the **bottom plate** first.
   - Position the **bracing** element next, ensuring the appropriate spacing relative to the hold down bolt.
   - Finally, secure with the hold down bolt and washer.

4. **Critical Details**:
   - **Overlap Requirement**: The bracing strap must adequately overlap with the framing members.
   - **Minimum Clearances**: Maintain specified clearances (50mm and 100mm) for effective load transfer and compliance with structural standards.

Walls 9.1 Smart Panel Wall to Mid-Floor Connections Floors may be face fixed to Smart wall panels with joist hangers or be supported by Smart wall systems with beam pockets and support posts. The image provided is a construction detail from a building product installation manual. Here’s a concise technical analysis:

1. **Components Shown:**
   - Joist hangers (JH 47 x 90, JH 47 x 120, JH 47 x 190, JH 95 x 165, JH 70 x 180)
   - Screws (Type 17-12g x 35mm Hex head)
   - Beam pocket structure
   - Supporting panels as per engineers' specifications.

2. **Key Measurements/Spacings:**
   - Joist sizes specified: 
     - JH 47 x 90
     - JH 47 x 120
     - JH 47 x 190
     - JH 95 x 165
     - JH 70 x 180
   - Screw specifications: 12g x 35mm.

3. **Assembly Order/Installation Sequence:**
   - The installation of joist hangers should be done first, ensuring the correct number of screws is used per flange as specified (1 for JH 47 x 90, 2 for JH 47 x 120, etc.).
   - Followed by the placement of supporting panels as indicated by design engineers.

4. **Critical Details:**
   - It's crucial not to overdrive screws into joist hangers to avoid damage, which might compromise structural integrity.

source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: 9.3 Lintels Are incorporated into our Smart Panels Lintel types a) Lintel supporting roof only b) Lintel supporting roof, wall and floor c) Lintel supporting floor only d) Lintel supporting roof and wall e) Lintel supporting wall and floor Lintels can be designed using NZS 3604:2011 and/or LVL manufactures span tables during the design stage. Sizes will need to be confirmed by structural engineer. 10. General NZSIP Smart Panel walls are manufactured with a nominal density. Batch testing is carried out at the factory for every project to ensure consistency is met. 10.1 Vertical Load Resistance Please contact NZSIP 10.2 Horizontal Load Resistance Please contact NZSIP 10.3 Bottom Plate Details Before Smart Wall system can be installed bottom plates and appropriate packing are required to be fixed into place. All bolts are at suitable lengths to secure plates with packing selected. Where bolts and washers are used for bottom plate, these need to be recessed into the bottom plate to ensure the Smart Wall panel will sit onto bottom plate. Please refer to relevant standard details on bottom plate dimensions. 10.4 Concrete Floors Wall connection details Packing to underside of bottom plate is required, options of packing material can be determined by designer from the below: A) Timber packing 115mm(W)x45mm; H1.2 treated continuous plate; B) Plywood Packing 115mm(W)x18mm continuous H3.1 CD plywood.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p35_diagram
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content:
DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
Based on the provided construction detail, here is the technical analysis:

1. **Components Shown:**
   - Bottom plate: 88mm x 45mm H1.2 treated SG8 timber.
   - Plywood packing or timber packing.
   - Damp Proof Course (DPC).
   - Concrete slab.
   - Fixings: M12 bolts with 550x5 washers.

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings:**
   - Bottom plate dimensions: 88mm width x 45mm height.
   - Wall thickness: 115mm.
   - Fixing spacing not specified in the diagram but must comply with NZS3604 standards.

3. **Assembly Order or Installation Sequence:**
   - Install the concrete slab.
   - Place DPC on the slab.
   - Position plywood or timber packing on top of the DPC.
   - Set the bottom plate over the packing.
   - Secure bottom plate to slab using specified fixings.

4. **Critical Details:**
   - Minimum clearance of the bottom plate from the concrete slab should be maintained as per DPC guidelines.
   - The bottom plate must be flush with the packing material to ensure proper alignment for subsequent components.
   - The chamfered top edges of the panel may indicate orientation for correct fitting. 

This concise summary provides a clear understanding of the installation detail depicted in the diagram.

content:
DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
1. **Components Shown:**
   - **Top and Bottom Plates:** Structural elements providing support for the wall framing.
   - **Side Plates:** Vertical members connected to the top and bottom plates.
   - **SB (Structural Bracing) Sheathing:** Provides lateral stability and surface for cladding attachment.
   - **Flashings:** Not explicitly mentioned but typically included for weatherproofing.
   - **Fixings:** D head ring shank nails and SPAX screws for securing components together.

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings:**
   - Fixings to be installed at 100mm centers (Cts).
   - First fixing starts 50mm from the edge of the SB sheathing.

3. **Assembly Order/Installation Sequence:**
   - Install top and bottom plates first.
   - Follow with the attachment of side plates.
   - Secure the plates using the specified fixings.

4. **Critical Details:**
   - The fixings must start at 50mm from the edge of the SB sheathing to ensure structural integrity.
   - Proper spacing of fixings at 100mm Cts is critical for load distribution.
   - Specific instructions for securing SIPs (Structural Insulated Panels) at corners are indicated, referring to length as per a separate detail (not included).

This concise analysis outlines the technical aspects necessary for understanding the installation process depicted in the diagram.

content: 12. Smart Panel Wall to Roof Junctions 12.1 NZSIP Smart Panel Roof Smart Walls are manufactured with a void to top side of panel for top plate continuous timber to be inserted on site. Where Smart Roof is applied to a Smart Wall system a “rake plate” to be provided to support panel pitch to the wall system. Smart Roof support fixing is required at 200mm crs for all supporting structure Nailing of all panel splines still required Roof Ridge; Ridge beam supporting SIP panels require SPAX screw fixings at 200crs with screw embedment at 45mm into beam. Packing to ridge beam to support Smart roof may be required as shown in standard detail SIP511. Roof Mid Support: Roof support beams are required to be fixed with 2x SPAX screws through panel with 45mm embedment into supporting beam as shown in standard details SIP 525/526. Interior Linings Plasterboard can be direct fixed to walls. If direct fixed consideration to services must be given as the cavity has been removed. 14.1 Ceilings Please refer to GIB site guide 15. Services Do not modify the panels to accommodate services in any way other than as described in this manual and the standard details. 15.1 Electrical Electrical services are to be located within the internal lining cavity. Small Penetrations to connect to electrical services to the exterior of the building are permitted provided they are installed as per the standard details. 15.2 Plumbing Plumbing services are to be located within the internal lining cavity. Small Penetrations to connect to plumbing services to the exterior of the building are permitted provided they are installed as per the standard details. 16. Thermal Performance High density polyurethane is one of the best performing forms of insulation for a given unit of thickness. When combined with the low levels of thermal bridging possible with structural insulated panels, the result is superior than most construction systems.

content: 16.1 Building code For housing and small buildings, compliance with New Zealand Building Code Clause H1 Energy Efficiency, in via the acceptable solution is NZS 4218. When using NZS 4218 to determine compliance, please refer to Installed R-values listed in this section 16.2 Compliance with the Passive House Standard and use in Passive House Planning Package (PHPP) software Smart Panels have been utilized in a number of Certified Passive House projects and are an excellent method of achieving the stringent performance requirements of the standard. For input of panels into PHPP, please contact NZSIP. 16.3 R - Values Thermal performance of individual components Timber framing Thermal conductivity = 0.13 W/(mK) Strand board Thermal conductivity = 0.13 W/(mK) Polyurethane foam Thermal conductivity = 0.023* W/(mK) *allowing for time dependent effects 17. Air Quality Internal Moisture The NZSIP Smart Panel building system will create an airtight, energy efficient building envelope. Due to the inherent airtightness of the NZSIP Smart Panel Building System, it is necessary for the designer to manage adequate air changes and suitable moisture control management to maximise energy savings, occupant comfort and building durability.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p50_c0
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: When constructed in accordance with this Appraisal the NZSIP Smart Panel Building System will assist with the system’s compliance with NZBC Clause E3.3.1. The NZSIP Smart Panel Building System will contribute to meeting the requirements of NZBC Acceptable Solution E3/AS1, Paragraph 1.1.1 (a) when the building design includes for an adequate combination of thermal resistance, ventilation and space temperature to all habitable spaces, bathrooms, laundries and other spaces where moisture may be generated or may accumulate. Ventilation must meet the performance requirements of NZBC Clause G4.3.1. Floors, walls and roofs complying with the Schedule Method for Compliance with Clause H1.3.2 (E) will have adequate thermal resistance to comply with NZBC Acceptable Solution E3/AS1. Wet areas are spaces where sanitary fixtures and sanitary appliances are located such as bathrooms, toilets, laundries and kitchens. There are two general categories of wet areas as follows: Water Splash – These are areas subject to intermittent splashing of water such as around baths, vanities, tubs and sinks. Shower Areas – These are areas subject to frequent and heavy water splash such as enclosed showers, unenclosed shower zones and showers over baths. Both the above wet area categories must be finished with surfaces and joints that are impervious and easily cleaned. In addition, shower areas must be waterproofed.

chunk_id: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section_p50_c1
source: NZ SIP Technical Manual Fasteners Section
content: hower zones and showers over baths. Both the above wet area categories must be finished with surfaces and joints that are impervious and easily cleaned. In addition, shower areas must be waterproofed. This can be achieved using proprietary rigid shower lining systems, flexible vinyl shower wall finish, or tiling. Tiled shower areas must include a wet area waterproofing membrane system under the tiles. 17.1 Ventilation The typical NZSIP Smart Panel construction creates an airtight, energy efficient building envelope. Due to the inherent airtightness of the NZSIP Smart Panel Building System some permanent ventilation, not reliant on window openings, must be provided in wet areas, such as bathrooms and laundries. The Technical Literature contains details for how this may be achieved. Vented windows, wall or ceiling mounted extract fans, or similar fittings are recommended in all building wet areas. Extract fans for moisture laden air must be vented externally. Due to the airtight performance of the NZSIP type construction, the use of mechanical ventilation is required. It is recommended that the minimum design ventilation rate of 0.35ach but no less than 7.5l/s person. (ASHRAE 62-1999) Natural ventilation must also be provided with the minimum area of openable window as 5% of the floor area in each room.

DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
1. **Components Shown**:
   - **Bottom Plates**: Double bottom plates are noted, which are a common element in framing.
   - **Precast or Chemset Bolts**: These are used to secure the bottom plates to the concrete foundation or pile floor system.
   - **Insulation**: An insulated dado is indicated, which is likely to enhance thermal performance.
   - **Building Control Officer (BCO)**: Representation indicating the need for inspection.

2. **Key Measurements/Spacings**:
   - The diagram specifies a 115mm vertical dimension for the bottom plate setup.
   - The positioning of hold-down bolts is referenced but specific spacings are not provided in the diagram.

3. **Assembly Order/Installation Sequence**:
   - Place the double bottom plates on the concrete foundation or pile system.
   - Secure with precast or chemset hold-down bolts as specified by engineering and architectural details.
   - Ensure the plates are square and aligned with the insulated dado.

4. **Critical Details**:
   - The diagram stresses the importance of overlaps in the bottom plates to ensure structural integrity.
   - Minimum clearances and gaps should be observed between the plates and adjacent materials to prevent moisture retention and facilitate airflow.
   - The BCO's involvement indicates a need for adherence to local building codes and standards.

This concise description captures the technical aspects of the bottom plate setup as indicated in the diagram.

   - Specific measurements are not visible in the provided diagram. However, the connection points between panels and base plates would typically require careful consideration of spacing for fasteners.

3. **Assembly Order or Installation Sequence:**
   - The installation sequence begins with the placement of Smart Wall panels.
   - Followed by the Smart Roof panels being installed on top of the wall panels.
   - Application of tapes over exposed panel joints and the base plate connection to the slab should occur as the last step in that sequence.

4. **Critical Details:**
   - **Overlaps**: Tapes should overlap the edges of panel joints to ensure effective sealing against water ingress.
   - **Gaps**: No explicit gaps are indicated, but the fit between panels is critical for maintaining structural integrity and weathertightness.
   - **Minimum Clearances**: Specific clearances are not detailed, but typically, minimum clearances should be maintained above ground level to

content: 7_Self-Drilling Screws.qxp 20/1/2010 0:02 Page 175 SS EE LL FF -- DD RR II LL LL II NN GG THE BUILDEXWARRANTY Buildex fasteners are made to exacting high standards of quality, subjected to strict inspection and testing procedures. Buildex is so confident that it can guarantee the highest quality and performance of its fasteners that it has backed it up with the BuildexWarranty, an industry first. The Buildex Warranty applies to Climaseal 3, Climaseal 4 & ZACS 4 coated roofing screws with ShankGuard and fully threaded roofing and cladding screws. It guarantees against the loss of structural integrity due to the effects of corrosion or metallurgical defects. Buildex Corporate Profile ITW Buildex is Australia’s leading manufacturer and supplier of self-drilling screws and fasteners. Established in 1917, the head office is in Moorabbin,Victoria. The on-site manufacturing plant produces hundreds of millions of painting and stainless steel fasteners are made inspection and test procedures. ITW Buildex is quality endorsed to ISO 9002 and is committed to developing modern, innovative products utilising the latest technology available worldwide. 175

chunk_id: Paslode NZ Nails BRANZ Appraisal 546_p1_c0
source: Paslode NZ Nails BRANZ Appraisal 546
content: Appraisal No. 546 [2022] PASLODE NAILS Appraisal No. 546 (2022) This Appraisal replaces BRANZ Appraisal No. 546 (2017) BRANZ Appraisals Product Technical Assessments of 1.1 Paslode Nails covered by this Appraisal include bright steel wire nails, mechanically galvanised products for building and nails, hot-dip galvanised nails, coated hot-dip galvanised nails and stainless steel nails. Paslode construction. Nails are available in collated format, in a range of sizes, and are designed for use with Paslode nail guns or are manually fixed. Scope 2.1 This Appraisal covers the material durability performance of different Paslode Nails when used in timbers with different treatments, treated in accordance with NZS 3640 and used in accordance with NZS 3602, to comply with the New Zealand Building Code (NZBC) durability requirements. Timber treatments assessed include copper chrome arsenate (CCA), copper azole (CuAz), alkaline copper quaternary (ACQ) and light organic solvent preservative (LOSP). ITW New Zealand Ltd Building Regulations T/A Paslode New Zealand PO Box 100 303 New Zealand Building Code (NZBC) North Shore Mail Centre 3.1 In the opinion of BRANZ, Paslode Nails, if used, installed and maintained in accordance with the North Shore City statements of this Appraisal, will meet or contribute to meeting the following provisions of the Ph: 09 477 3000 NZBC: Fax: 09 477 3001 Clause B1 STRUCTURE: Performance B1.3.1, B1.3.2 and B1.3.4.

Paslode Nails contribute to meeting Web: www.paslode.co.nz this requirement for the relevant loads from B1.3.3. See Paragraph 7.1. Clause B2 DURABILITY: Performance B2.3.1 (a) not less than 50 years and B2.3.1 (b) 15 years. Paslode Nails meet these requirements. See Paragraphs 8.1-8.3. Clause F2 HAZARDOUS BUILDING MATERIALS: Performance F2.3.1. Paslode Nails meet this requirement. chunk_id: Paslode NZ Nails BRANZ Appraisal 546_p3_c0
source: Paslode NZ Nails BRANZ Appraisal 546
content: BRANZ Appraisal PASLODE NAILS Appraisal No. 546 (2022) 02 August 2022 Appraisal No. 546 [2022] 4.2 The Paslode Nail packaging has different coloured labels for the different nail types as described in Table 2. Table 2: Collated nails label descriptions Nail Material Label Colour Bright steel White Mechanically galvanised steel Tan Hot-dip galvanised steel, with and without black coating Yellow Stainless steel Red 4.3 Collated Paslode Nails for use with Paslode nail guns are generally collated together with paper strips down both sides of the nails, however some of the nails are collated together with plastic. 4.4 Only Paslode nailing tools, as supplied by Paslode New Zealand, are to be used to install Paslode collated nails. The Paslode nail guns have not been assessed by BRANZ and are outside the scope of this Appraisal. Handling and Storage 5.1 Paslode Nails should be stored in a clean, dry area until they are used. Technical Literature 6.1 No specific Technical Literature is referenced by this Appraisal. Design Information Structure 7.1 Connections incorporating Paslode Nails must be designed and installed in accordance with the relevant non-specific design standards, e.g. NZS 3604, or as specified by specific engineering design to the relevant loading and design standards. 7.2 Where a proprietary system manufacturer specifies standard nails, permission must be obtained from them before Paslode Nails are substituted.

chunk_id: Paslode NZ Nails BRANZ Appraisal 546_p3_c1
source: Paslode NZ Nails BRANZ Appraisal 546
content: g design to the relevant loading and design standards. 7.2 Where a proprietary system manufacturer specifies standard nails, permission must be obtained from them before Paslode Nails are substituted. Durability 8.1 Paslode Nails are expected to have a serviceable life of at least 15 or 50 years (depending on their use) provided that they are installed and maintained in accordance with this Appraisal. 8.2 Table 3 gives information on where each of the types of Paslode Nails identified in Table 1 may be used, based on the timber use, the environment, the timber moisture content and the timber treatment. Table 3 is for Corrosion Zone B, as defined by NZS 3604. Table 4 gives the same information for Corrosion Zones C and D, as defined by NZS 3604. 8.3 If ACQ-based or CuAz-based treatments are used for timber Hazard Classes H3.2, H4 or H5, then only stainless steel fasteners should be used in exposed or sheltered locations in accordance with NZS 3604, Clause 4.4.4. There is very little of these timber treatments in use in New Zealand at this time, and most timber is treated with CCA. Maintenance 9.1 Paslode Nails need little or no maintenance in themselves. Where paint or coatings are required to ensure the required design life, then these must be maintained as per the relevant manufacturer’s instructions. Pg 3 Readers are advised to check the validity of this Appraisal by referring to the Valid Appraisals listing on the BRANZ website, or by contacting BRANZ.

chunk_id: Paslode NZ Nails BRANZ Appraisal 546_p6_c0
source: Paslode NZ Nails BRANZ Appraisal 546
content: BRANZ Appraisal PASLODE NAILS Appraisal No. 546 (2022) 02 August 2022 Appraisal No. 546 [2022] Installation Information Installation Skill Level Requirement 10.1 Paslode Nails are installed either with the aid of Paslode nailing guns or are manually fixed, and can be done so by any competent person. Health and Safety 11.1 Guidelines for the safe use of portable mechanically powered nailers and staplers are available from the Department of Labour, and all aspects of these should be followed when using nail guns. Basis of Appraisal The following is a summary of the technical investigations carried out: Tests 12.1 The following testing on Paslode Nails has been completed by BRANZ: ¬ Accelerated corrosion testing on Paslode Nails in timbers with different Hazard Class treatment levels. Other Investigations 13.1 A durability opinion has been provided by BRANZ technical experts. 13.2 Observations have been made by BRANZ to assess the practicability of installation, and to examine completed installations. Quality 14.1 The methods of quality control for the manufacture of Paslode Nails has been examined by BRANZ and found to be satisfactory. 14.2 The quality of the nails supplied by Paslode New Zealand is the responsibility of Paslode New Zealand. 14.3 Designers are responsible for the design and specification of joints incorporating Paslode Nails. 14.4 Quality of installation on-site of Paslode Nails is the responsibility of the installer.

chunk_id: Paslode NZ Nails BRANZ Appraisal 546_p6_c1
source: Paslode NZ Nails BRANZ Appraisal 546
content: nd. 14.3 Designers are responsible for the design and specification of joints incorporating Paslode Nails. 14.4 Quality of installation on-site of Paslode Nails is the responsibility of the installer. 14.5 Building owners are responsible for the maintenance of their buildings. Sources of Information ¬ NZS 3602:2003 Timber and wood-based products for use in building. ¬ NZS 3604:2011 Timber-framed buildings. ¬ NZS 3640:2003 Chemical preservation of round and sawn timber. ¬ Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment Record of amendments - Acceptable Solutions, Verification Methods and handbooks. ¬ The Building Regulations 1992. THREE PASLODE PURLIN NAILS REPLACE 1/10G SELF DRILLING TYPE 17 SCREW, 80MM LONG IF INSTALLED ACCORDING TO DIRECTION New Zealand Building Code (NZBC) The product will, if employed in accordance with the supplier's installation and maintenance requirements, assist with meeting the following provisions of the building code: Clause B1 Structure: Performance B1.3.1, B1.3.2, B1.3.3, B1.3.3(a), B1.3.3(b), B1.3.3(f), B1.3.3(g), B1.3.3(h) Clause B2 Durability: Performance B2.3.1, B2.3.1(a) Clause F2 Hazardous building materials: Performance F2.3.1 Notes BRANZ APPRAISED (No. 1249) ALTERNATE FIXING FOR ROOF PURLIN AND BATTEN CONNECTIONS TYPE T AS PER NZS 3604 TABLES 2.2, 10.10, A10.10, 10.12, A10.12, 15.9 AND A15.9. THREE PASLODE PURLIN NAILS REPLACE 1/10G SELF DRILLING TYPE 17 SCREW, 80MM LONG IF INSTALLED ACCORDING TO DIRECTION. Supporting Evidence The product has and can make available the following additional evidence to support the above statements: BRANZ Appraisal 1249(2023) Product Criteria Design requirements The Paslode Purlin Nails are used as an alternative fixing method for purlins to rafters or to the top chord of trusses. The Joint is formed by installing three Paslode Purlin Nails through the purlin into the rafter or truss at each intersecting connection.

chunk_id: Paslode Impulse Purlin Nails Technical_p1_c2
source: Paslode Impulse Purlin Nails Technical
content: method for purlins to rafters or to the top chord of trusses. The Joint is formed by installing three Paslode Purlin Nails through the purlin into the rafter or truss at each intersecting connection. This joint meets the 2.4 kN alternative fixing capacity requirement of NZS 3604 Table 2.2, fixing type T. Installed nails must be spaced over the contact area of purlin and rafter to avoid any potential splitting. Where a proprietary system manufacturer specifies standard nails, permission must be obtained from them before Paslode nails are substituted. Installation requirements Paslode Purlin Nails are installed with the aid of Paslode nailing guns and can be done so by any competent person. Maintenance requirements Paslode Purlin Nails need little or no maintenance in themselves. Claddings over these connections are required to ensure the required design life, then these must be maintained as per the relevant manufacturers instructions.

chunk_id: Paslode Purlin Nails BRANZ Appraisal_p2_c0
source: Paslode Purlin Nails BRANZ Appraisal
content: BRANZ Appraisal PASLODE PURLIN NAILS Appraisal No. 1249 (2023) 19 May 2023 Appraisal No. 1249 (2023) Technical Specification General 4.1 Paslode Purlin Nails are 80 mm x 3.15 mm in size and have a shank ring height of 36 mm. The tips are dipped in resin from 38 mm to 40 mm from the nail tip. 4.2 Paslode Purlin Nails have an offset RounDrive nail head and can be identified by the letter “P” stamped on the centre of the head. The nails are collated with the use of tan coloured Paslode RounDrive Nailing Systems branded packaging. Accessories 4.3 Only Paslode nail guns, supplied by Paslode New Zealand, are to be used to install Paslode Purlin nails. The Paslode nail guns have not been assessed by BRANZ and are outside the scope of this Appraisal. Handling and Storage 5.1 Paslode Purlin Nails must be stored in a clean, dry area until they are used. Technical Literature 6.1 No specific Technical Literature is referenced by this Appraisal. Design Information Structure 7.1 Paslode Purlin Nails are used as an alternative fixing method for purlins to rafters or to the top chord of trusses in timber-framed buildings designed in accordance with NZS 3604. 7.2 Purlins must be SG6, SG8 or SG10 timber and are limited to a maximum thickness of 45 mm. 7.3 Three Paslode Purlin Nails are fixed through the purlin into the rafter or truss at each intersecting connection. This joint meets the 2.4 kN alternative fixing capacity requirement of NZS 3604 Table 2.2, fixing type ‘T’.

chunk_id: Paslode Purlin Nails BRANZ Appraisal_p2_c1
source: Paslode Purlin Nails BRANZ Appraisal
content: Nails are fixed through the purlin into the rafter or truss at each intersecting connection. This joint meets the 2.4 kN alternative fixing capacity requirement of NZS 3604 Table 2.2, fixing type ‘T’. 7.4 Where a proprietary system manufacturer specifies standard nails, permission must be obtained from the manufacturer before Paslode Purlin Nails are substituted. 7.5 Paslode Purlin Nails must be embedded flush to countersunk, diagonally spaced in accordance with the detail on the packaging. Nails must be spaced over the contact area of purlin and rafter to avoid any potential splitting. Durability 8.1 Paslode Purlin Nails are expected to have a serviceable life of at least 50 years. Maintenance 9.1 No maintenance is required for Paslode Purlin Nails. Annual inspections of the roof cladding system must be made to ensure all aspects remain in a weatherproof condition. Installation Information Installation Skill Level Requirement 10.1 Paslode Purlin Nails are installed with the aid of Paslode nailing guns and can be done so by any competent person. Health and Safety 11.1 Guidelines for the safe use of portable mechanically powered nailers and staplers are available from the Department of Labour, and all aspects of these should be followed when using nail guns. Other Investigations 13.1 A durability opinion has been provided by BRANZ technical experts. 13.2 Observations have been made by BRANZ to assess the practicability of installation, and to examine completed installations. Quality 14.1 The methods of quality control for the manufacture of Paslode Purlin Nails has been examined by BRANZ and found to be satisfactory. 14.2 The quality of the nails supplied by Paslode New Zealand is the responsibility of Paslode New Zealand. 14.3 Designers are responsible for the design and specification of joints incorporating Paslode Purlin Nails. 14.4 Quality of installation on-site of Paslode Purlin Nails is the responsibility of the installer. 14.5 Building owners are responsible for the maintenance of their buildings. Impulse XP The Paslode Lithium Ion cordless Impulse nailer has provided framers and renovators the ability to wood frame without air hoses for over 25 years. New Li-ion battery technology drives 50% more nails per charge. Framing Nailer 2-times faster charge time; 2 minute quick charge drives up to 200 nails. Tool free depth of drive adjustment, non slip grip, dual position utility hook, sequential operation triggers.
